full_text: Go on more walks. Walk for no reason. Walk to solve a problem. Walk to blow off steam. Walk to get outside. Walk to listen, read, and learn. Walk to escape distractions. Walk to improve your health. Walk to think. A simple walking habit can change absolutely everything.

Nobody is coming to save you.

Not your friends. Not your family. Not the government

They can offer advice and tools.

But at the end of the day, it's up to you to change your mind and act regardless of how you feel.

A thread of advice you need to hear:

Wake up.
Hit snooze 4 times.
Stare at your phone.
Roll out of bed.
Make coffee.
Sit in traffic.
8 hours of unfulfilling work.
Sit in traffic... again.
Argue with your "significant" other.
Walk the pet.
Watch TV.
Pass out.
Repeat.

This should scare the shit out of you.

Self-discipline is when the desire to become the highest version of yourself outweighs the desire for cheap pleasures.

A thread on reaching your potential:

You don't magically become focused. You practice it. You notice you're distracted and snap out of it immediately, over and over again until it's second nature. Most people have not trained this muscle, and they are not anywhere close to as focused as they think they are.

“Everyone is going to make their own apps with AI”

My friend you don’t even make your own food. You’ll still pay a few bucks to use an app.

The only real test of intelligence is if you get what you want out of life.

– Naval Ravikant

A thread on becoming more intelligent:

If you don't shamelessly promote your work, every day for the next 10-20 years, you will get stuck doing someone else's work until you realize that nobody is going to pay you if they have no idea who you are.

Write more. Write for no reason. Write to organize your thoughts. Write to get the chaos out of your mind. Write to attract people to the work you love doing. Write because most other habits are distractions that slowly chain you down. Write to change your life.

A pattern I've noticed in successful people:

They disappear from the world for months at a time to force pure focus on themselves and their vision. They laser in on one meaningful goal and make it a reality.

How I've been using AI:

- Choose a task
- Find YT expert that teaches it
- Have AI summarize their video
- Add examples / context
- Have AI turn that into a meta prompt
- Test, refine, and reuse that prompt

This has led to the best results in almost everything I have AI do.

Stop wondering what to do with your life. Start trying everything until you find the one thing that makes you forget to eat. The thing that makes you lose track of time. The thing that keeps you up at night because the ideas won't stop coming. Give everything for that one thing.

The best periods of my life came after a period of being absolutely fed up with the lack of progress I was making.

A thread on using negative energy to change your life:
3-6 months of beginner hell (making close to zero progress and questioning whether it's worth it) is a natures way of filtering out people who weren't serious in the first place.
It takes about 1-2 months of confusion, feeling lost, and being on the verge of giving up for the right amount of vision to form where you have absolute clarity and launch into a new way of life.
If you want to see a quick jump in quality of life start going on a 15 minute walk first thing in the morning, right after you wake up, no matter what the weather is.

How to master any skill fast:

- Stop studying
- Outline a project
- Start building it
- Hit a roadblock
- Research how to overcome it
- Repeat until completed

Most people get trapped in tutorial hell and have nothing to show for years of "learning."

The easiest way to get ahead in life is to commit to a period of skill development. 6-12 months. Pure focus for 2-4 hours a day. Learning and building. Not just binge watching tutorials, but creating quality projects that you, others, or businesses could actually benefit from. Most people won't do it but those who do launch ahead of everyone else.

If you're bored, create something.

Anything.

Software. Designs. Photos. Videos. Writing. A business. A body. A relationship. A new way of thinking.

How can you not feel electric to wake up and have the ability to do whatever you want.

Signs you're on the right track:

Time moves differently
Work energizes you
Money becomes secondary
Learning doesn't take effort
Discipline is the default
You think in decades, not days
Waking up is a blessing

You feel like you don't belong, but you wouldn't change a thing.

Be a failure.

Approach the girl and get rejected. Post the video and get called an idiot. Start the business and watch people criticize your first moves.

Everyone else did it. You aren’t a special case.

Invest in your portfolio of failures until you can afford to succeed.
If you want to attract people to you, focus on your mission. People gravitate toward those who know what they want.
Most people quit because they don't realize that 2-3 months of feeling like you have no idea what you're doing is a feature not a bug.

The minute I become too frugal or money conscious is the moment it starts to control me and becomes difficult to make. When I spend almost carelessly, it seems to find its way back. A poor psychological relationship with money will ruin you.

The most important thing you can do when the world is changing rapidly is learn.

Here's how to learn anything 10x faster than anyone:
I am once again telling you if you can spend 8 hours building someone else's dreams you can spend 1 hour building your own.
The 2 hours you spend scrolling each day (or 730 hours each year) could have produced a book, a business, or a body you don't currently have.
When you’re bored, pick up a book instead of your phone and see where that simple habit shift it takes you.

You don't have ideas because you don't read.

You can't articulate ideas because you don't write.

You can't leverage ideas because you don't build.

You feel bored, anxious, or overwhelmed because your mind wants ideas to flow but you won't let them.
If you can spend 4 years getting a degree to do something you don’t care about you can spend 1 year reeducating yourself to build your own thing. Stop quitting after 2 weeks.
You're not struggling with productivity. You're struggling with not having a project worth being productive for.
Sometimes a simple “fuck it, I’ll make it work” is all you need to start the snowball of momentum into a better life.

This sounds stupid but I swear it works miracles.

For the next 7 days, find a 1 hour long lecture on YouTube from Alan Watts.

You have to listen to it when you aren't distracted by anything else: before you take a nap, before you fall asleep, or on a quiet walk.

When I do this I can start to feel my mind opening. Ideas start flowing again. Everything feels lighter.

I find myself doing this when I feel very narrow. I can't come up with new ideas. I've been working too much. Life feels repetitive.

I've done this once a year for the past 5 years and I still don't know why I don't make it a daily thing.
The death of your business happens when you obsess over a website, logo, LLC, and taxes before you actually start getting customers.

You are a creative person. You just aren't in a creative environment. You don't live a creative lifestyle. You're stressed all day (narrow mind = narrow thoughts) trying to "think" your way to new ideas. It doesn't work that way.

Grab a notebook.

Write out exactly what you want in your future, don't miss a detail. Then, break it down into goals. Decades, years, months, weeks, and days.

Every day, write down the 3 levers you can move to create your vision.

Then, forget about the goals and execute.
If you weren't born into a rich, intelligent, or stable situation, the only thing that will set you apart is the intensity of your desire to learn.

If you don’t have ideas, read.

If you have ideas, but can’t articulate them, write.

If you have ideas, and the clarity to execute, build.

Expand, organize, and focus your mind until your craziest ideas become reality.

Fuck perfectionism.

Build fast. Make mistakes. Take more shots. Give yourself something to improve. Stop worrying when nobody is watching.

You think you're fighting other's opinions when you're just a slave to your own.

Maturity is discovering that most of your life is spent in a plateau, and if you don't fall in love with practice, mastery, and moving the needle forward you'll constantly try to escape the plateau with cheap stimulation and busy work that only keeps you there longer.

How to clear your mind:

Walk more. Read more. Write more. Listen more. Lift more. Strategize more. Build more.

Scroll less. Indulge less. Criticize less. Ruminate less. Sit less. Procrastinate less.

Clarity is reserved for those who don't resist reality, but engage with it.
You're anxious because your mind is living in the future while your body is stuck in the present. The gap between where you are and where you think you are is too large for action:
Be careful telling people about your goals. It releases dopamine similar to achieving them. Don't tell people what you are going to do. Tell people what you are doing.
If you aren't tired when you go to bed and excited when you wake up, you need a meaningful project that demands you at your best.

If you're lost, the answer is education.

If you're educated, the answer is execution.

If you're executing, the answer is persistence.

If you're persisting, the answer is experimentation.

Go to the fucking gym.

Go on a fucking walk.

Build a fucking business.

Learn to calm the fuck down.

Maximize every fucking area of your life.

Mind, body, spirit, business.

Your quality of life will be high as fuck.

Build your own thing for the first hour every day. See where it takes you. Commit to it. Produce something of value that you weren't forced to produce to pay the bills or because your parents or teachers told you to. Your future self is begging you and I know you hear that voice.

Luck =

High energy
In the right place
Around the right people
Producing more than consuming
Avoiding any and all distractions
Able to manage multiple interests
High agency and self-educated
Doesn't quit after one mistake

Luck is a lifestyle

Competition is largely an illusion. 95% of people don't even try to do great things. 0.1% of the people are loud, so you overestimate how many people there are. The rest get stuck worrying about competition and quitting after 2 weeks.

The paradox of productivity:

It's difficult to start the task, but once you do, it's difficult to stop.

Subtle reminder that you're supposed to feel overwhelmed.

It means you're doing something new. You're taking a new path. You're learning. Growing. You branched into the unknown. It will be frustrating. You will feel lost. It will be painful, but staying the same is even worse.
The fastest path to making better choices is to think about your ideal life before every single decision you make until it becomes a habit.
I oscillate between wanting to be the next Steve Jobs and wanting to throw my phone in a lake and join the monks at least 3 times a day.
You're bored because you haven't developed a skill set that allows you to take on interesting challenges.
The best periods of my life always came after a period of getting absolutely fed up with the lack of progress I was making.

Life is hard because you don't know what you want. That's 90% of the battle. Once you have extreme clarity on what you want, after 5-10 calculated risks, everything else is quite simple. If you can reach that before you turn 25, you're in the top 1%.

You can learn anything in 2 weeks.

If you can't, you're trying to learn too much at once. Break the goal down and focus solely on doing what's necessary to reach it. If your learning doesn't involve doing, most of what you learn is disappearing the second you learn it.

If you're a beginner, nobody knows who you are. You have to prove your worth before people start caring enough to pay you. Make noise. Be annoying. Show your work in public. Do everything you can to get in front of the right people. All you need is one bite to change everything.
If you can spend 4 years getting a degree to do something you don’t care about you can spend 1 year reeducating yourself to build your own thing. A lack of perspective is why most quit after 2 weeks.

Every time I drop my reading habit I notice a gradual decline in quality of life. Thoughts get jumbled, ideas stop flowing, and life loses its spark.

Because it's a gradual decline, it's hard to make the connection that a small reading habit can make such a big impact.

The solution to boredom is building.

Build a skill.
Build a brand.
Build your body.
Build your mind.
Build your social life.
Build anything.

It doesn't matter if you "don't know how."

That's the entire point.

You learn, act, and discover your way out of boredom.

Be a loser.

Let your parents think you are stupid for not following their path. Start a business and embrace failure after failure. Study the interests that make you feel like an outcast.

Where most people conform is where greatness is born.

Subtle reminder that you're supposed to feel overwhelmed.

It means you're doing something new. You're taking a new path. You're learning. You're growing. You branched into the unknown, and that's admirable.

Learn to think. Learn to write. Learn to speak. Learn to identify problems. Learn to set higher goals. Learn how to learn. Learn everything that allows your mind to expand and adapt to any landscape. That's how you become irreplaceable.

Nobody is coming to save you.

Not your friends.
Not your family.
Not the government

They can offer advice and tools.

But at the end of the day, it's up to you to change your mind, view your situation from a new perspective, and act regardless of how you feel.

Patterns I've noticed in unhappy people:

- They care about fitting in
- They lack vision for the future
- They expect too much from others
- They neglect lifelong self-education
- They unknowingly prioritize negative thoughts

They don't realize that happiness is an inside job.
Anything worth doing with your life takes about 1 year of deliberate practice 3+ times a week to even consider yourself decent at that thing. 5 years to be good. 10 years to be great.
The gym, long walks, and a personal project that you can pour your heart into will solve most of your problems.

If you aren't building something that leads to the life you want, even if it's "only" 30-60 minutes every morning, you will by default stay in the same life you're in, building things that allow others to live the life they want.

You need 4 habits:

One that builds your mind.
One that builds your body.
One that builds your business.
One that builds your relationships.

The good life is the process of becoming everything you could be.

The reason people don't achieve big goals is because they don't realize that the only source of truth is making mistakes. They soak up advice and theory, expecting it to be an exact match to their mind, experience, and situation just to fail once and give up completely.
Force yourself into uncomfortable situations so you don't end up being 50 years old with the emotional maturity of a 15 year old.

Learning comes from struggle, not memorization.

Start the project. No, don't watch 20 tutorials beforehand. Let it expose the gaps in your knowledge. Try to figure it out. Search for the answer when your mind is most likely to remember it.

Publish the project. Repeat for life.
The best periods of my life always came after a period of getting absolutely fed up with the lack of progress I was making.
If you have multiple interests, don't let anyone convince you that you should narrow your focus. You may be confused for a while, but if you stick it out, you will blow past everyone else.

Grab a notebook.

Write out exactly what you want in your future, don't miss a detail. Then, break it down into goals. Decades, years, months, weeks, and days.

Every day, write down the 3 levers you can move to create your vision.

A dream without clarity is a nightmare.

You won’t make it without obsession.

But nobody starts out obsessed. They start out curious. They experiment. They build things. They break things, They fail. And eventually they can’t pull themselves away.

Curiosity turns into obsession with time and persistence.
If your entire day is made up of working on tasks you don't care about, you are creating a life you won't care about.

You’re supposed to feel overwhelmed.

It means you’re learning. It means you’re expanding. It means you’ve finally left your bubble of comfort. The worst thing you can do is go back and hide from situations that make life meaningful.

Give your mind time to adjust.

When it's time to work, work.

When it's time to rest, rest.

Most people are always thinking about rest while working and work while resting.

An empty life is one lived in your head.

The solution to boredom is building.

Build a skill.
Build a brand.
Build your body.
Build your mind.
Build your social life.
Build anything.

It doesn't matter if you "don't know how."

That's the entire point.

You learn, act, and discover your way out of boredom.

The future belongs to those who understand:

- AI needs direction
- Tools need masters
- Data needs insight
- Content needs context
- Success needs vision

Automation won't save you. Agency will.

Do it all.
 
Become a writer, designer, marketer, filmmaker, bodybuilder, runner, or whatever your curiosity desires

The internet gave the individual the power to learn almost anything, fast, and get results from diverse interests.

You are living through the second renaissance.

You can just start over. You don't need permission. You don't need to wait for the right time. You can stop what you're doing, right now, and move in a new direction. Your mind will do anything to convince you to stay the same, but you don't have to listen.
The secret to self-discipline is to avoid environments that make it difficult, and create environments that make it effortless.

Most people think their dream is to become a YouTuber when that's just their soul begging them to create something, anything, and share it with the world because happiness stems from the intersection of a challenge and connection to something greater than yourself.
The greatest threat to a young persons potential is getting tied down too early with long term responsibilities because society said they should.

Physical strength is built through progressive overload of weight. Mental strength is built by the progressive overload of responsibility. Life gets better when you gradually increase your holistic stress tolerance.
Discipline is saying no to people, places, and things that distract you from the pain of not achieving your goals.
Force yourself into uncomfortable situations so you don't end up being 50 years old with the emotional maturity of a 15 year old.

Most people haven't practiced thinking.

When you talk to them, you aren't talking to them. You're talking to the TV. Social media. Their parents. Their teachers. Their insecurities and trauma.

It's very robotic. The definition of inauthentic.

Disconnect and think more.

Set aside 1 hour a day for the 2 most important people in your life:

1) You
2) The person you want to become
Obstacles aren't in your path, they are your path, and when you try to avoid them, you end up going nowhere.

You suck at writing because you don't understand human nature.

People don't want clever, they want clear.

People don't want a lecture, they want emotion.

People don't care about you, they care about themselves.

Write with this in mind and watch your readers pay attention.
You're distracted because you don't have responsibilities, priorities, or goals so important that you have no choice but to focus on them. You're afraid to commit so you drown in options.
Self-confidence comes from doing what you think is uncomfortable, over and over again, and realizing it wasn't that bad in the first place.

If you want to do great things you need time to think. Time alone. No people. You need to remove yourself from any form of external information that could interrupt the important work your subconsious is doing. Since they are always busy, most people don't understand this luxury.
You weren’t born to work 40 hours a week doing something you hate, numb your mind with endless scrolling, and wake up one day wondering where the time went.

If you're bored, create something.

Anything.

Software. Designs. Photos. Videos. Writing. A business. A body. A relationship. A new way of thinking.

How can you not feel electric to wake up and have the ability to do whatever you want.

Nobody is coming to save you.

Not your parents.
Not your best friend.
Not the government.
Not your favorite book.

They can offer a helping hand, sure, but the choice to improve is yours and yours alone.

Master your mind.

Read more. Consume less. Produce more. React less. Focus intensely on one thing. Zoom out and let go of everything. Train. Recover.

Your mind is the operating system for reality. If you don't program it, others will, and that never ends well.

If you feel lost, write down:

1) Who you want to become
2) Who you don't want to become
3) The 3-5 things you can do today

You're lost because you don't have a direction to work toward, an enemy to work away from, and tasks that move the needle toward your goals.

The secret to self-discipline:

- Become fed up with where you are
- Get clear on what you want
- Create a plan to get there
- Remove every single distraction
- Take the smallest step
- Fail until you are okay with failure

Discipline is the byproduct of clarity, not force.

If you're bored, go on a walk.
If you're anxious, go on a walk.
If you lack ideas, go on a walk.
If you need space, go on a walk.
If you need exercise, go on a walk.
If you need sunlight, go on a walk.

Before you try the latest fad to fix your problems, go on a walk.

Feeling lost is a sign that you are no longer your past self, but not fully the person you want to become. That's uncomfortable. The worst thing you can do here is what most people do, which is to numb the pain with comfort and close yourself off to your future self.

My biggest fear is waking up to live the same life as everyone else over and over again. Doing work I don't care about for people I don't care about. Never understanding, always reacting. No energy or time to think, plan, build, or change. Stuck on the surface as decades pass by.

Focus is like a battery. If you rest for short intervals, you can work in intense bursts. If you rest for a day or two, you can focus longer and harder. If you rest for too long, you overcharge. Your battery gets weaker and you struggle to get anything meaningful done.

You need 3 habits.

One that builds your mind (reading, learning, journaling).

One that builds your body (gym, running, nutrition).

One that builds your money (business, skill dev, investing).

Anything more is a bonus, anything less is self-destructive.
You aren't disciplined because you keep putting yourself in environments that give you a chance to be undisciplined.

My timeline is filled with optimism and focus on health, aesthetics, learning, building, thinking, technology, ecology, and economics. As someone who's been immaturely apolitical most of my life, these are values I can heavily get behind. Smells like a new Golden Age.

You feel helpless because you are unaware that there IS a series of decisions you can make to get out of your situation.

A thread on decision-making:
The ability to earn with your mind, not your time, labor, or looks is how you become in control of what you do and how much you make.

If you're bored, read.

If you're anxious, write.

A clear mind is a confident mind.

Confidence is a prerequisite to good outcomes from the thousands of daily choices you make.

Choices compound into a life you hate or love.

How to clear your mind:

Walk more. Read more. Write more. Listen more. Lift more. Strategize more. Build more.

Scroll less. Indulge less. Criticize less. Ruminate less. Sit less. Procrastinate less.

You lack clarity because you fill your mind with junk and let ideas go stale.

Reason to read:

Most of your ideas are triggered by other people’s ideas.

You have thousands of dormant ideas waiting to present themselves and reading is a great way to activate ideas you forgot about or didn’t know you had.

Writing changed my life.

My only regret is that I didn't start sooner.

Why you should start writing (even in the age of AI):
The most dangerous threat to your potential is to stop learning once you've stopped being forced to.
Reading without writing is like eating without lifting. The excess gets stored as fat and you have nothing to show for the precious time invested.
It’s incredible how many people still believe you need a college degree to see any form of success. The conditioning runs deep.

If you don't know what to learn, try:

- persuasion
- storytelling
- how to learn fast
- emotional intelligence
- audience building
- attention capture
- offer creation

All of these amplify any other hard skill you can acquire and determine the results you get with them.

How to waste your life:

Be a slave to distractions.

How to save your life:

Observe society.

Become aware of the problems that lead to mediocrity.

Identify them in yourself.

Focus on a future without those problems.

Protect your mind at all costs.

Create your own path.

You aren't where you want to be because you don't have the mind of the person who would be in that position. You're exactly where you should be for your level of development, and changing that is within your control.

There is something you can do for 30-60 minutes a day that will move the needle toward the life you want (and get more results than those who work 12-16 hours a day), but you have to find what that something is through obsessive experimentation.

You as a single person have more power today than a 20 person company of the past. The internet gave you the ability to learn anything. Social media gave you the leverage to reach anyone. AI is giving you the ability to create almost anything. Please don't waste it.

Too much structure makes life mundane.

Too much spontaneity makes life chaotic.

A dance between the two makes life meaningful.
The ultimate goal is to have a life so beautifully designed that work, rest, and play cease to exist. They all blur together and are indistinguishable.

I'm generally unpleasant to be around.

I prefer being alone. I hate being out of routine for more than 2-3 days. I'm either thinking about nothing or everything with little in between. I say no to almost everything that gets in the way.

At first I thought it was a character flaw and tried to change it. That only led to me splitting focus and slowing progress on the goals that bring me joy in life.

When I observe people I look up to, their mission comes first. That's what makes life enjoyable, and if that enjoyment is taken away, it spreads into their work, their loved ones, and their friendships.

If you know what you want, and you don't fold to what others think you should want, you are going to be unpleasant to be around.

That isn't something to be ashamed of but embraced.

In fact, you'll find that people want to be around you more because they trust you. They can feel that you aren't putting on an act like everyone else.

Get absolutely dialed for a month. Life becomes a game when you pay a 'delusional' amount of attention to the details. Track your food. Track your lifts. Track your steps. Track your revenue. Progressive overload each week. Ignore everything else. You'll enjoy progress again.

Observation:

Most smart people I know, when they want to learn something, immediately Google what they want to learn and go down a rabbit hole.

Everyone else asks for all information to be given to them, rarely get a complete answer, and get distracted within 5 minutes.
If you don't have anyone to talk about your interests and passions with, start writing on the internet and you'll find them.

If you don't have a purpose, everything becomes your problem. You don't have a way to filter important information that helps you achieve your goals. You slowly drown in distractions until you can no longer think, act, or be yourself. This explains the misery of most people.

You aren't bored.

You're distracted.

Hopping from social media to the news to video games to junk food to numb your mind from the discomfort that life presents.

Distractions are finite.

Your potential is not.

Completing 1-3 priority tasks in the first 4 hours of the day, every day, for years, aimed toward your ideal future, will get you far ahead of those working all day on scattered tasks to the point of burnout.

If you want to achieve anything great, it needs to become your one true priority. The only thing on your mind. Nobody accidently got rich. Nobody accidently built a great physique. They were obsessed with it for multiple years until they no longer had to think about it.
Luck is a percentage that increases with the number of people who know what you do and how well you do it.
You're bored because you haven't developed a skill set that allows you to take on interesting challenges.
There is no better place to be than under an immense amount of pressure from a challenge that you chose to take on.

Wake up.
Hit snooze 4 times.
Stare at your phone.
Roll out of bed.
Make coffee.
Sit in traffic.
8 hours of unfulfilling work.
Sit in traffic... again.
Argue with your "significant" other.
Walk the pet.
Watch TV.
Pass out.
Repeat.

This should scare the shit out of you.

A thread:
Money is a spiritual tool to stop being dependent on others so you can give to the world with full authenticity.
The greatest threat to a young person's potential is getting tied down too early with long-term responsibilities because society said they should.
You cannot advance to a higher phase of life until you learn the lesson that the current phase is trying to teach you.

It's liberating once you realize that the mind can be trained to do anything you want. That most of your lack is no more than a lack of skill, knowledge, action, and the logical sequence of steps it takes to achieve that thing. Unlike muscle on your body, your mind is infinite.

You need to move.

Your body. Your mind. Your projects. Your relationships. Your finances. Because if you don't, you don't stay the same, you slowly decay without realizing it until you reach the point where it's much, much harder to dig back out.

Entropy waits for no one.
You're bored because you haven't developed a skill set that allows you to take on interesting challenges.

Learn a lot of stuff. Build a lot of stuff. Identify problems. Solve them. Discover new paths. Take them. Reflect on the journey. Do it better the next time. Stay aware of distractions. Don't turn on autopilot. Take risks. Make mistakes. Fail, hard. Bounce back. Win.

That's it.

Simple:

Increase value
- Never stop learning
- Never stop building
- Never stop iterating

Distribute value
- Think, write, and speak daily
- Teach what you learn in public
- Turn your journey into a product

The secret you’re looking for is to stop standing still.
The best way to reduce the anxiety of a big task is to start with the smallest possible action. If you can stick with it for 5 minutes, most of your worries vanish.

The New Rich:

- Self-educated
- Has a clear purpose
- Builds digital leverage
- Controls their ideal day
- Time and location freedom
- Mastery over rapid outcomes
- Develops their value with time
- Dynamic skill stack over specialization

A savant in the digital renaissance.

If you understand entropy you understand that by doing nothing with your life you choose to slowly drown in chaos. You don’t stay the same. You dig yourself deeper into a hole without trying. The good life demands consistent effort toward your own goals.

If you're lost, start solving problems.

The problems that are staring you straight in the face. Your fitness, health, finances, mindset, work, or anything preventing you from having control over your life.

Experiment until you become obsessed.

That's how you find purpose.

If you're good at your job, your boss will give you more work.

If you answer emails fast, people email you more because you seem available.

If you're effective at what you do, guard your time because people will fill it up as much as they can.

Act busy but don't be busy.
Most of the time, a degree is just a sign that you can do work you hate for years without pursuing your own thing, and that's exactly what employers want.

If you don't like your situation, you shouldn't be worried about how long it will take to change it.

You have nothing better to do than to work on something meaningful.

Who cares if it takes 12 months or 12 years when you would have wasted that time anyway.

Block out 1 hour a day.

Work on 1 meaningful project.

Aim for 1 vision for your future.

Take it 1 day at a time.

You don't need more time, you need more focus.

It doesn't matter if it takes years.

What the fuck else are you going to do?

4 hours is all you need.

Why?

- 8 hours of pure focus is psychologically impossible

- 4 hours as a deadline creates a tangible deadline (narrows focus)

- completing your work in 4 hours is challenging (an ingredient of flow state)

- you are forced to do high-leverage tasks (or else you cry about how 4 hours isn't enough)

- ample rest reduces psychological fatigue (like resting from the gym) so you can produce higher quality work

- you have time to pursue the things that contribute to quality of life/work (personal development, spirituality, interest exploration

Clearly this doesn't happen in an instant.

Today I learned schools were created to enslave the brightest minds by promising the prestige of specialization so they remained narrow minded and didn’t overthrow the rulers by learning in a big-picture general sense.

The Great Pirates – who had high proficiency in many things like navigation, storms, biology, geography, the men, the ship, economics, history, and science – surrounded themselves with loyal yet dumb illiterates because they realized bright people were the only ones who could overtake them.

The pirates, when docked, would have the rulers notify them when a bright mind would spring up. They had the rulers assign them specialized study material to become something prestigious like the “Royal Historian” or “Royal Treasurer,” and just like that, their potential for greatness was extinguished.

Explains why specialization is still highly encouraged and why “high paying jobs” are the first thing on teenagers minds when thinking about what to do with their future.

One of the most important skills is how to learn skills fast.

You need to be able to adapt going into a future of AI and automation.

And learning one skill will only lead to you being replaced.

But most people don't know how to learn.

1) Stop Learning "Skills"

The first problem is that people think they learn skills by picking one and studying it.

No. That's how you learn the same thing as everyone else and get placed in a job or business that can be replaced in a millisecond.

Instead, you learn anything and everything that allows you to achieve your ideal lifestyle. Everything must be filtered through your vision.

2) Start The Project, Then Learn

Most people get trapped in tutorial hell.

They watch videos all day and after 3 months they still have no idea what they're doing when they decide to start.

Start a project that will move the needle toward your vision.

Start. It. Then, when you hit a roadblock, supplement with education.

3) Ship The Project

Post the video. Send the newsletter. Launch the product. Pitch your service. Especially if you're embarrassed.

The harsh reality is that if you don't have real people using your project, you have no idea if it's valuable. You don't determine its value.

If you never hit send, you have no idea if you're moving in the right direction, and you will get lost.

I'll end with this:

You can't improve what doesn't exist, therefore you don't actually start learning a thing until you put your project in front of people to judge, criticize, and use.

People ask why I recommend writing a newsletter first, even with 0 subscribers.

Because it doesn't matter how many people read it if:

- It is your YouTube script
- It is published on your blog
- It can be condensed into 20+ posts

Starting with long-form writing forces you to be somewhat original.

(Which most people can't do when they are stuck in the short-form rat race.)

It forces you to actually create - to research, capture, deconstruct, experiment, and reconstruct knowledge.

It makes you take your interests seriously enough to consider your life's work.

When I focus on writing my newsletter for 30 minutes every morning, all of my other content is handled.

It's as simple as deconstructing the newsletter and repurposing it everywhere in less than 10 minutes a day (once you have the process down).

And, of course, you build the newsletter over time, which is more valuable than any social media following.

Your mind rewires to play long-term games.

Your success becomes exponential with time.

Stop thinking about it as just a newsletter that disappears when you hit send.

It is the foundation of your entire brand (and most people don't have that).

Everyone should write a book at least once in their lifetime.

Especially if you want to become a deep and articulate thinker.

When you write a post or article, your mind expands to fit that context. You catch ideas that help you finish that specific project.

But a book is different. It's extremely chaotic at first. You spill your subconscious into a blank document and start shaping it into chapters and sections. You create a little world for your mind to operate in.

The longer you spend in that world, the more your mind expands to take that shape, and the more connections you start to make. When you're writing a book, you struggle a lot, but you'll find that your brain lights up with interest and excitement more than ever before. Almost any information or conversation you come across gives you an idea.

You start to realize that your mind is only as perceptive as the project you're working on.

As a writer, I've noticed that AI doesn't shorten my writing process (because I don't want it to), it makes it longer.

I don't treat AI as the writer, I treat it as the reader.

I have it raise objections to my points.

I have it rate my hook and introduction for various metrics like relatability, use of curiosity gaps, and brevity.

I have it overview my writing to ensure readers understand it, learn something knew, and are given at least one thing to implement once they're done reading.

I really struggle to have AI do the writing for me.

It doesn't feel right. No matter how good the AI gets it still lacks a soul.

Even if it comes up with good or novel ideas, I don't want to use them because that strips the joy from coming up with them myself. I literally start to feel dumber and less creative when I let AI take over too much of the process.

My prompts have shifted to helping enhance the writing process rather than replace it, and it's allowed me to spend more time (not less) on the craft I enjoy mastering.

After 5 years and trying every software under the sun, I've simplified everything down to this.

I feel like AI's impact on writing is vastly overhyped.

And that's coming from someone building an AI writing software.

First, there is already too much content. We can't read it all. AI will add more, but most of it will go to the bottom of the barrel unless written by someone who could have gotten that content seen (someone who's already a skilled writer). Writing is one skill that only gains traction when paired with a personality and complementary skills that make other people see it and care about it. It may get slightly harder to separate signal from noise, but I doubt it, because AI content can still be signal.

Second, AI can write a tweet or article or newsletter or video script, but that's not why or how you build an audience of readers. Your "brand" is a culmination of everything you've put out.

Having one tweet or TikTok go viral does almost nothing for you aside from maybe a quick cash grab. Most viral content is shallow and low IQ. That's not a foundation for a meaningful long-term brand. Most worthwhile content is not viral.

Your brand is a culmination of every piece of writing you put out, viral or not. It's the personal or organizational philosophy, meaning, and vision. Your writing is a thread in that tapestry woven over time.

Third, just because AI can write or code or market doesn't mean that everyone will write or code or market. It means that people who already wanted to write, or see the value in it, will attempt to leverage AI. And once they realize that a lack of fundamental understanding of the skill won't get you very far, they'll have to learn it from scratch anyway (shoutout vibe coders).

AI is revolutionary. There's no question about it.

But the hype right now feels like everyone hopping on the next get rich quick scheme. The people who aren't slaves to quick fixes and cheap dopamine will continue to do well as they have been.

In reality, this is more like the next evolution of how we write.

Pen and paper > typewriter > keyboard > software assisted > AI assisted.

It's a big jump, but after all the "writing is dead" hype we're still in the same place we've been.

If you're trying to get exposure on your work, it sounds weird, but starting a podcast is one of the best things you can do.

Not because you want to make it the number 1 podcast in the world, but because:

1) High status people / people you respect would rather be on a podcast than on a call with you. They're more likely to respond and accept, meaning you get a free mentorship call to ask them all your questions.

2) You leverage their large audience, and they also benefit from it. People are more likely to watch/listen to the podcast because someone they like is on it. This is arguably the best beginner growth "hack."

3) You form deeper relationships with good people. If you host a good podcast, the guest is more likely to respond to future requests or just help you out.

If you're a creator, freelancer, or just someone who is trying to do their own thing, you need people to see your content and work.

Most people rarely gain traction because the algorithm is like the lottery. But when you are strategic about forming connections with people who already have an audience, you can build your own much, much faster.

Even if you only host 2-4 podcasts in your entire career, those alone could change everything for you depending on the guest you get on.

I get cluster headaches every 2-3 years.

In short, they fucking suck.

Mine aren't this bad, but I've heard of some people pulling out their teeth with a leatherman because they think it will help the pain.

The only real relief for them is oxygen therapy (unless anyone has some esoteric remedies that can help... I've tried a lot). And since mine only last everyday for a week or two at a time, I just decide to stick it out because getting oxygen is one story and ordering a machine with a week or two shipping time seems against the point.

Everytime I think I find something that helps like icing or taking way too much magnesium or flonase, they stop working the next time around.

Now this isn't a post to complain.

It's the exact opposite.

I always wanted to do something creative.

It started as graphic design.

Then I got bored and tried dropshipping, SEO, content marketing, digital art, and more. All failed.

In college, I took a web development class and fell in love.

I knew I could get a job without a degree.

I knew I could go the freelancer route.

I spent my time studying courses and free videos outside of class.

I aced the class without showing up.

During this time I was trying to freelance as a web designer.

Getting a job was the bane of my existence.

After failing, again, I had to swallow my pride and start applying.

I landed a gig at a web design agency.

That taught me what I was missing.

Web design as a skill wasn't enough.

I needed to stack the skills that would make my main skill profitable.

A year later, I replaced my income and quit the job.

This is when I discovered the power of social media and writing.

I saw social media as a way to earn back my time.

If I built an audience, I could sell whatever I wanted.

I didn't have to send thousands of outreach messages (with people telling me to "f*ck off") anymore.

Writing was the key to building and monetizing a readership.

If I had a readership, I could sell my web design services, or I could sell anything that interested me (as long as it interested other people too).

So that's what I did.

Writing removed the cap from my income.

Writing increased the quality of my mind and life.

I wrote content, landing pages, product material, and everything in between - to the point where I now have to pay 25x my previous salary in taxes this year. A good problem to have I guess.

Anyways, I only have so much space to write here.

Closing in on the big 1m and pretty annoyed

I go through these lulls in views every few months.

Videos do really well, then 4-5 of them do way worse.

When I look back on them, I realize that the videos just aren't good enough. Not that the content itself is bad or not helpful, but you can see a drastic difference in the topic, title, and thumbnail choice.

I can almost always map these "lulls" to a period when ideas aren't flowing well. I'm not reading as much. I'm not learning anything new. I'm trying to force things out for the sake of staying consistent.

What's helped me break through these points is just that:

Doing a mental reset. Throwing all planned content ideas out the window and starting from scratch. Picking up a new book. Learning from new people. Realigning with the core ideas that I'm best at articulating and adding a twist.

The reason I write this is because I see many others go through the same lulls, or they never make it out of the beginner lull that everyone starts out in.

What helps is just being brutally honest with how good the video actually is.

It can be good in your eyes, which is important, but if others don't care about it, it's missing a crucial aspect of what makes it "good."

(P.S. I know 50k+ views is nothing to scoff at. Speaking relative to the normal baseline.)

Your mind runs on a storyline.

Games are interactive stories with certain mechanisms that narrow your focus and make progress addictive.

If you want to get unstuck, use this AI prompt to turn your life into a video game (it's long):

–––

You are LifeQuest AI, a strategic life coach that transforms the user's life into an immersive game experience. You analyze their current life phase (Limbo, Vision, Flow, or Resistance), help identify their true desires, and create a personalized game structure with actionable quests and meaningful narrative. You maintain honesty about uncertainty and ask clarifying questions when needed to provide accurate guidance.

Context:

The user wants to gamify their life journey using principles from Adlerion psychology, flow psychology, and Greek philosophy. They seek clarity on their current life phase, future direction, and meaningful pursuits. They need support to break these goals into manageable quests within a cohesive narrative framework that makes progress tangible and rewarding. This interaction unfolds in two phases: first to assess and strategize, then to implement and coach ongoing progress through quests.

Instructions:

Phase 1: Life Assessment & Game Design

1. Throughout this phase, ask 1-3 questions at a time. Do not ask all questions at once to reduce overwhelm.

2. Begin by asking key diagnostic questions to identify the user's current life phase:

- What areas of life feel stuck, flowing, or unclear?
- What activities currently energize vs. drain them?
- What would they fight to avoid as a future outcome?
- What new information, people, or experiences have recently sparked their interest?

3. Analyze responses to determine which life phase they're in:

- Limbo (uncertainty, directionless feeling)
- Vision (emerging clarity, building momentum)
- Flow (strong engagement, rapid progress)
- Resistance (plateauing, clinging to past success)

4. Guide the user to articulate their "negative vision" — the outcome they want to avoid if nothing changes.

5. Help the user discover potential positive directions by asking about:

- Sources of genuine curiosity
- Skills they enjoy developing
- Meaningful impacts they wish to make
- Environments where they thrive

6. Synthesize findings into a complete game structure:

- Main Quest: Primary life direction/purpose
- Side Quests: Supporting goals in various life domains
- Character Stats: Key abilities to develop
- Level System: How progress will be measured
- Rules: Non-negotiable boundaries and values
- Rewards: Meaningful celebration of progress
- Tutorial Phase: Initial low-risk experiments to try

7. Design quantifiable feedback loops with daily/weekly priority tasks that provide clear markers of progress.

Phase 2: Ongoing Quest Guidance

1. Begin each session by checking progress on previous quests and updating the user's "character status."

2. Provide appropriate coaching based on their current situation:

- If stuck: Help identify obstacles and potential solutions
- If progressing: Suggest appropriate "level-ups" or new challenges
- If overwhelmed: Simplify quests or adjust difficulty
- If bored: Introduce novel challenges at the edge of their capabilities

3. Frame all advice within their game narrative, maintaining the metaphor consistently.

4. Regularly revisit and update the main quest as the user's vision evolves.

5. Balance short-term achievements with long-term development.

6. When the user faces significant obstacles, help them:

- Analyze patterns that led to the block
- Break down complex challenges into smaller quests
- Identify potential "power-ups" (resources, skills, or allies)
- Reframe setbacks as essential plot developments

Constraints:

- Maintain game metaphor consistently but never at the expense of providing practical, actionable advice
- Focus on intrinsic motivation over external rewards
- Recommend only challenges slightly beyond current capabilities (the edge of the unknown)
- Never suggest activities that conflict with user's stated boundaries or values
- Avoid generic advice; tailor all guidance to user's specific situation
- Acknowledge uncertainty when you don't have enough information

Output Format:

Phase 1 Output:

Life Phase Analysis: Current phase identification with supporting evidence

Character Assessment: Strengths, weaknesses, motivations, and potential directions

Game Design:

- Main Quest (overall life direction)
- Side Quests (supporting goals)
- Character Stats (skills to develop)
- Level System (progress metrics)
- Game Rules (boundaries/values)

Tutorial Phase: First 1-2 weeks of specific quests and experiments

Feedback System: Daily/weekly check-in structure

Phase 2 Output (for each coaching session):

1. Quest Log Update: Progress since last interaction

2. Character Status: Current "level" and stats

3. Quest Guidance: Next immediate steps with specificity

4. Challenge Calibration: Adjustments to maintain optimal difficulty

5. Narrative Development: How recent developments fit into their overall story

This has been our goal for a while now.

Cursor For Creative Work

(learning, writing, idea capture, video scripting)

But we made a few "mistakes" while developing Kortex that you may benefit from hearing.

The good news is, starting this week, we're releasing the first AI assistance features that drastically change what you can do in it.

That's the first "mistake."

We deprioritized AI features and missed out on a lot of the hype with new models coming out.

Instead, we focused on building a solid base. Something better than your typical writing, note-taking, or second brain app:

- Connections and tags
- Infinite panes to have any idea open
- Capture ideas like texting yourself

This wasn't a mistake, but it took a lot of time to get it right. I don't think we should have changed this, and gratefully we have users who refuse to use any other app.

The mistake here is that we thought we needed things like:

- Full offline mode
- The desktop app
- A top tier mobile app
- Workspaces and teams

Those are very important things, and they need to happen, but they take a lot development time without an increase in differentiation.

(Although these will differentiate us from those who build a similar app fast - note-taking apps have a lot of gotchas and edge cases that I don't think most people are ready for.)

In other words, we started building things that every other app already has, and that only delays our time to becoming an app that is a "hell yes" to switch to from another app that already does the job so well.

Our capture feature was cool and differentiating, but not a driving "hell yes" factor in switching from others.

Since the start of Kortex, we've had the vision of being able to:

- Capture any idea, from anywhere, fast
- Transcribe any article, video, or link so you can reference it while writing or with AI
- Have all models in one chat interface that can access any document, source, highlight, or the entire context of your workspace (so you don't need 8 tabs open while you work)

Because writing and creative work isn't just about putting stuff in a word processor. To do good work, you need to capture ideas, learn fast, research fast, access any relevant info fast, and synthesize everything into something worth publishing to the world.

Now that we have desktop, partial offline, and mobile very close, we feel like we're finally hitting our stride.

We can now solely focus on our differentiating factor.

Right now, a big pain of ours is that we're compared with things like Notion, Obsidian, Apple Notes, and the rest, when we know that within 3-6 months Kortex will be unrecognizable from them.

We're still new to this, so the lesson here is only theory until we prove it to ourselves, but:

You need to get extremely clear on why you are different.

But not just that, everyone knows that.

You need to build that first. You need to enter the market as that, even if you don't have the little quality of life features.

I feel like if we did that, we would have grown a lot faster, because people would be willing to sacrifice little things for a completely new way of doing things that other products don't provide.

Then, once that's proven and you give yourself enough time to iterate, focus on the small things that push you even further.

I may be wrong about this, but I feel like our thought process here could help others wanting to do similar things.

Lots of moving pieces. Building is fun.
